Hi Mike,

 

I guess I didn't write as clear as I should... QA wants to run some
tests, I guess, more functional than unit test... and a senior colleague
has suggested to me to use JUnit. I have never written any test for QA
before and I don't know what tool is better out there and so I just take
advice from the person who has used JUnit before and highly recommend
it. As for testing subset of the tests, it's just an option, when they
want to check something specifically and not have to test the whole suit
(for example, some tests fail and they need to re-test only those with
different parameters on another run). 

 

Vietchau

Hi Vietchau --

I have no further suggestions about the techniques to use to do this
(I've
done what David suggests when I needed such support)

On a different note though, my I ask about the following:

>> I need to create unit tests for QA and they require an option to
select
which test to run at runtime.

I'm curious about how (why?) "QA" is using JUnit tests.

Typically (although certainly not by rule), JUnit tests are used more
for
"programmer tests", most often unit (or even "object") tests. Is this
the
case for you?

If so, what value does your "QA" find from these types of tests?
Additionally, if so, might it be a risky idea to run only select tests
as
opposed to the collective suite?

If not, being new to JUnit, it might be advisable for you to consider
utilizing JUnit for this purpose. (And, in this case, there is certainly
plenty of info available on this mailing list and even more in more
formal
print that would be of great value to you)

Just food for thought. Cheers!..
--MB
